The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 16 October 1996:
Taxation Administration Act—Determinations 1996 Nos. TD 96/42. TD 96/43.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1996Cognate bills:INCOME TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996INCOME TAX (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is wish of the committee to debate this order of the day concurrently with the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 and the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996. There being no objections, the chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the three cognate bills, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 is probably the most important part of the first instalment of the new law. It will establish a new Income Tax Assessment Act which will be built up progressively to replace the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, as that act is rewritten.

SPEECH.PARA: The second of the cognate bills is the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 and is intended to amend other Commonwealth acts that contain references to the income tax law, to ensure that they reflect the amendments proposed in the Income Tax Assessment Bill. It will also close off the application of provisions of the 1936 act that have been rewritten in the assessment bill.

The third of the cognate bills is the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996, which will explain when and where the new law will start to apply. As a general rule, the new law will come into operation on 1 July 1996 and will first apply in the 1996‐97 income year.

These bills were introduced in the House on 19 June 1996 and were referred for consideration by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The reason for these amendments is to provide a definite start date which is not likely to result in retrospectivity and which will allow more time for transition to the new law.

I would like to refer to nine specific items included in those three cognate bills. First of all, and not in any order of importance, is the tax rebate for low income aged persons. This amendment is to implement an election commitment to provide a rebate to certain persons of pension age who are in the same taxable income range as pensioners who are entitled to the pensioner rebate. The second of the items refers to rebatable annuities, and the losers in this will be the members of the superannuation and insurance industries who are marketing products that take advantage of the loophole that currently exists. This item will close off that loophole.

Some additional points in regard to these amendments are that the measures maintain the current treatment of certain annuities purchased on or before 12 January 1987, and the measures apply from the date of the press release announcing the amendment. This approach was necessary as a prior warning of the closing of the loophole, which unfortunately may have resulted in last‐minute activity to take advantage of the anomaly.

The next item that I wish to raise is the medical expenses rebate which is a very important initiative of the government. The medical expenses rebate replaced the concessional expenditure rebate for medical expenses in the 1985‐86 income year. Originally, the rebate was calculated at the rate of 30 cents in the dollar on medical expenses in excess of $1,000 in an income year. Between 1985‐86 and 1991‐92 the rate of rebate was reduced progressively to 20 cents in the dollar on the excess above the threshold. There will be no additional compliance costs in regard to this measure as taxpayers will not be required to keep additional records and, to qualify for the rebate, taxpayers will have to keep records of medical expenses as they do under the existing law.

The next item is the sale of mining rights. There is no policy justification for providing an incentive for the metals and minerals currently listed and not providing similar incentives for the discovery of others. Equity investment in small and medium enterprises—small businesses, medium sized businesses—will assist small and medium enterprises to obtain finances and the winners will be the SMEs and the institutions which make such investments to the SMEs.

The general outline for cooperative companies is that the measure will repeal paragraph 120(1)(c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to remove the tax deduction that eligible cooperatives have been entitled to, in respect of certain government loans used to purchase assets. The reason for this amendment is to repeal the paragraph, which is consistent with competitive neutrality principles and the government's policy of removing anomalies from the tax system.

The next item is the tax exempt entities which will give effect to measures first announced by the previous government on 1 July 1995 to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act and to allocate incoming and outgoing gains and losses to the periods before or after the exemptions to which they belong. The amendments will apply to entities that become taxable on or after 3 July 1995.
The other two points I wish to raise are housekeeping measures: the infrastructure borrowings and research and development activities. That is all I would like to raise in regard to these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, would you please accept my apologies for being a few minutes late this morning. As you would appreciate, it is a very busy time for the opposition so I was delayed for a few moments and as my colleague, Mr Bob Brown, the member for Charlton, correctly points out, we have been busy trying to bring down the government.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to this package of bills, it is the first instalment of the rewrite of the income tax law under the tax law improvement project. The project was established in 1994 by the former Labor government to restructure, renumber and rewrite the income tax law in plain English. This was obviously a very important measure; public trust in our laws in Australia relies on the ability of citizens to understand the law. Many Australians, of course, feel that they have not got access to tax accountants, tax lawyers, shelf companies, unit trusts, offshore trusts, family trusts; they have not got the same access in the taxation system as those who hold wealth and high income in this country. As they have trouble comprehending the complexity of the income tax laws, this undermines public trust and confidence in the system.

BREAK.PARA: Average citizens—average PAYE taxpayers—are not able to get across the huge complexity of these laws, while other citizens have access to those resources that bring them within the ambit of tax minimisation and tax avoidance. I noted with interest, trawling through the declaration of members' interests, that the Liberal party, and certainly the members in this place, have shown far greater attachment to family trusts than family values in their rhetoric and I think this is indicative of the double standards that apply within the Australian taxation system. The average citizen is struggling hard to understand the complexity of these laws, while other citizens have the resources available to them to use the best lawyers and accountants to take advantage of tax minimisation possibilities.

The Income Tax Assessment Bill proposes to replace major sections of the existing legislation, the Income Tax Amendment Act 1936. Further tranches of replacement provisions will be enacted in the future, probably on an annual basis. The government has some significant further draft legislation which has already been released in the public arena for comment which builds on the set of reforms started by the former Labor government. Exposure drafts 7 and 8 have been released which cover important areas such as depreciation and capital allowances for primary producers. In due course, the opposition looks forward to these measures and rewrites flowing through into firm legislative proposals.

The Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill now before the committee proposes to amend other pieces of Commonwealth legislation that contain references to the Income Tax Assessment Act to ensure that these are consistent with the new assessment bill provisions.

The Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill explains how the assessment bill will commence to apply. When introduced, it was intended that these new provisions would apply from 1 July this year; that is, for the 1996‐97 financial tax year. However, the proposed commencement date is to be delayed a year, a matter I will return to later in my remarks.

These bills—with some minor changes—were introduced by Labor last year. Earlier this year, the bills were referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for public consultation, including hearings, and this process has now been completed.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts issued report No. 345 in August which generally supported the passage of the bills, with some amendments. I note that the government is yet to respond to this report formally, even though it is proceeding with the debate on this particular bill, and I hope that the government expedites its response to the committee's report and findings. The joint committee made some technical criticisms of some rewritten provisions. However, the substantial criticism is that the provisions should operate completely prospectively. That is, the bill should not commence until the 1997‐98 tax financial year.

The government has accepted the recommendation and the opposition will support such an amendment. Perhaps, ironically, for such simplifying legislation, the actual amendments to achieve this one-year deferral are quite large and complex in their detail.

The second area of amendment is to introduce new rules which will make it easier for a listed public company to provide continuity of beneficial ownership, which is a pre‐condition for claiming prior year and current year losses. These new rules will provide an alternative to the existing test and should hopefully reduce the cost of compliance. The opposition is pleased to support these amendments.

In addition, the government is planning to move a large number of technical amendments to correct technical deficiencies identified by the joint committee and/or relevant stakeholders. I note that they were circulated in the House just yesterday.

In conclusion on these matters, the opposition supports these bills because they will improve the legislation that business and the rest of the community have to deal with, hopefully leading to a better business environment with lower compliance costs. It is also worth remembering that these bills are the result of the tax law improvement process that was initiated and undertaken during our time in office. In essence, this is a Labor initiative that we trust the government will carry well into the future. We also trust that it will not find any handicaps or mishaps under the administration of the Treasurer, Mr Costello.

I have been noting that out of his administration there is a thing emerging in this place—in public life in Australia—that I think is best described as the Costello curse. Jim Short, Assistant Treasurer, is gone—Costello curse. Mr Gibson, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer—gone the same way. The Premiers Conference—spoiled; we moved from cooperative federalism in Australia to destructive federalism through the Treasurer's actions. Of course, the incident with Mr Greenspan has ricocheted around the financial markets of the globe. The government's relationship with Senator Harradine has been sullied by the Treasurer's imprudent remarks in the House not so long ago and, of course, the Development Allowance Authority and the tollway concessions have been the subject of an enormous backflip by the Treasurer. This is a litany of maladministration within the Treasurer's portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the member for Werriwa will address the bill before the House.
—I am just coming to that, of course, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I am sure you will.

—Well, you caught me midstream. I was saying that the provisions now before the committee are also within the Treasurer's administration. You can understand my apprehension, my fear, that they too might be caught up with this Costello curse. I have looked at the record; I have looked at these incidents; I have been following them closely as a good member would do, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sure you have even noticed them and you might just see the connection, one by one. I am not superstitious by nature; I believe in rational debate and substance of facts and argument, the power of reason in public life. But these things really are of concern, and I would hate to see such an important measure as this taxation simplification and improvement program being caught within those instances of maladministration. I trust that that is not the case. I know the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) is here looking after these matters. He is not so cursed as his boss, the Treasurer, and I look forward to a successful program being brought to its conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate about these three bills that we are in the process of dealing with cognately, but most of my comments will be restricted to the exercise which has been undertaken in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996. As the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) indicated, and others have indicated in connection with this question, it arose initially from an exercise which was undertaken by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the previous parliament, when a recommendation was made by that committee that the opportunity be taken to rewrite and to simplify the existing tax act.

SPEECH.PARA: That proposal was accepted by the government and then the exercise was undertaken by the tax law improvement project. I acknowledge the presence in the advisers' box of Mr Brian Nolan, who was the convenor, coordinator and leader of that particular improvement project. I want to acknowledge and place on the record again my appreciation, and that of the committee and of the parliament, for the efforts of Mr Nolan and those other people who are here today who also participated in one way or another in that exercise. It was to my mind, and to the minds of the committee members, a very valuable exercise. We would hope that the purposes for which that exercise was undertaken will be achieved when the bill, when it becomes an act, becomes operative and becomes available to all of those people who are involved with it in one way or another.

Naturally, I harbour reservations about the extent to which the ordinary taxpayer will refer to it. Ordinary taxpayers did not refer to the previous act, nor will they refer to this act. Nor will many of the advisers refer to this act, as they depended—quite understandably—upon the handouts from the taxation department previously. But the thing about it is that there is no doubt that ordinary taxpayers will, if they wish to go to the act, better understand its provisions, and be better able, hopefully, to more correctly relate their activities and the conduct of their affairs to it. And it is to be hoped that those tax advisers—people in the professional tax industry—will refer more frequently to it because it is more understandable.

The exercise was undertaken because the original tax act, which this one now replaces, is the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, so it has been 60 years since any exercise of this kind has been undertaken. During those 60 years, as one might expect in an increasingly complex economy with increasingly sophisticated arrangements on the part of business and on the part of taxpayers arranging their affairs, governments, responding to those changing circumstances and seeking to clarify some aspects of the tax law or seeking to close loopholes which develop in the tax law, have introduced changes from time to time. That has been going on for 60 years.

When the previous government was elected in 1983, the Income Tax Assessment Act was 1,100 pages long. I remember being critical of the government that we replaced in 1983 because of that. I can understand why people like the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) is now being critical of the previous Labor government, because that 1,100 pages has grown to 3,300 pages over that 13‐year period. If we also include the legislative provisions which have became part of the Income Tax Assessment Act, it is closer to 5,000, and maybe even over 5,000 pages.

So it was necessary for this exercise to be undertaken. For those people who want a simple and easy reference to the way in which some of these apparent complexities have been overcome and the way in which the act has been simplified, there are any number of examples at the end of the explanatory memorandum. Let me place one of them on the record.

For the provisions of the act in relation to division 43, for example, the new law is contained within division 43‐10. It restates the provisions of the existing act, the previous law, which were contained within the following parts: 124ZC(1)(a) and (b), 124ZC(2)(a) and (b), 124ZC(2A)(a) and (b), 124ZC(3)(a) and (b), 124ZC(4)(a) and (b), 124ZC(4A)(a) and (b), 124ZH(1)(a) and (b), 124ZH(2)(a) and (b), and 124ZH(2A)(a) and (b). That is not bad.

I said to the previous Assistant Treasurer, George Gear, that if the exercise being undertaken to simplify the tax act was to make it more attractive for me to read before I went to sleep, then perhaps this one might serve the purpose. Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker, neither you nor I went to sleep pondering that ponderous previous Income Tax Assessment Act. So it has been a very useful exercise. The work that was undertaken by the tax law improvement project team, together with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, was very valuable.

BREAK.PARA: The exercise was designed to a large extent to reduce the problems of compliance and the costs associated with it. That is very difficult to estimate. The estimates vary from between $3 billion and $6 billion every year. We can do more with funds of that kind than having them going into the professional tax industry in order to clarify, interpret and apply the tax law.

Hopefully, this particular exercise will overcome that and those $3 billion to $6 billion every year will be applied to other more productive and useful purposes, including my constituents, many of whom could do with that sort of funding to replace a lot of the programs that are disappearing at the present time. There has been a need to overcome the complexity, ambiguity, uncertainty and, in some places, the apparent self‐contradictions that existed within the old act. We all hope that this present exercise will achieve that.

It was called the tax law improvement project. I do not want to make too much of that, but there is a suggestion in that title that the tax law was to be improved. That was not the purpose of the exercise. Neither Mr Nolan nor those people who worked with and for him in connection with it believed that that was the case. The exercise was designed to improve the way in which the tax law is stated—not to improve the law but to improve the way in which it is stated. That has been the result of it.

I want to make this observation: the problems of cost of compliance will not be overcome in any tax system, including Australia's—however we might rewrite the tax law—until the inherent underlying complexity of the tax system itself is overcome. This does not do it. Nor was it designed to—I am not suggesting that that was a deficiency in the work that was undertaken or of the rewritten tax act which is now made available to us; that was not the purpose of that exercise. But we do need to address it.

I know that one of the really big, contentious issues in this area was one which developed prior to and in connection with the federal election in 1993, and that was the question of a goods and services tax. It was believed that that would simplify the system. Yes, it would. So people might be entitled to say, `Well, Bob Brown, why don't you support it? You want the system simplified.' I will tell you why I would not support it—and this is relevant to this whole question.

I would not support it because, to my mind, the goods and services tax, in shifting the emphasis of tax from income tax to when people spend, would necessarily fall more heavily on those people who spend most of their income. And who are they? They are my constituents. What about those people who do not spend most of their income, those people whose income is such that they are able to accumulate wealth and hold their savings, their investments, their portfolios, in various types of security arrangements? There was no provision for an additional tax there. That is the main reason I opposed it.

I have always been of the opinion, and continue to be of the opinion, that one of the great difficulties inherent in that tax act and one of the basic underlying reasons for the complexity of it is the fact that we tax income. And in order to tax income you have to define income, you have to say what income is—and that is the problem. What is income? What things do we include in income? We used not to include capital gains. We used not to include fringe benefits. So any person who was able to arrange their affairs in such a way that the accumulation of their wealth came in non‐monetary forms avoided tax. That was quite apart from the sharks who evaded it and those people who deliberately manipulated the tax act to avoid it. Quite apart from them, there were people who were legitimately able to minimise the tax they paid—and that is a legitimate practice and a sensible and necessary one—by arranging their affairs in appropriate ways.

So there is the whole question of identifying income. But we can overcome that to a large extent by saying, `It does not matter where the income comes from, it does not matter what form it comes in. Apart from giving it away or burning it you can only do one of two things: you either spend it or you hold it.' And that can be identified. With a very sophisticated market arrangement you can tax when they spend. That is the GST, but let me add something: you tax what they hold as well. So you do not just tax my constituents who spend most of their income, you catch those people on the North Shore as well, the people who are able to put most of their income aside.

If we do that—if we tax what people spend and tax what people hold—I will endorse it. You do not then have to define what income is because it does not matter. That is my position, and I will continue to oppose indirect taxes being imposed on expenditure until we hit the wealth that people are accumulating at the same time. When we choose to tax both of those I will support it. That will remove the fundamental underlying complexity, ambiguity and uncertainty, and the self‐contradictory elements, of the Income Tax Assessment Act, however we might choose to restate it.

In relation to this exercise, let me refer to and put on the record some of the particular problems that the public accounts committee had to face in this exercise that it undertook. Firstly, after the matter was referred to it, the committee had to come to some decision about whether the project should proceed. Of course, the committee agreed that it should, and that was one of the recommendations.

Secondly, as all of the tax law was being rewritten and restated, the committee had to decide whether it should be introduced progressively, or held until it was completed and then introduced into the community all at once. We came down on the side of the first option because it is much better for it to be absorbed gradually, or intruded into the system, so that people become increasingly aware of it. This is one of the first stages in that process: the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 is being restated and completed, and now we feed that into the system.

The third question that we had to determine was whether the rewriting exercise should include restatements of the law and changes to it. We said, `No. That is not the purpose of the exercise.' We suggested that any changes should keep faith with the community so that they could not say,`This is just a swiftie. You say that you are just rewriting the law, but you are changing the law.' We said that, to keep faith with the community, if we changed the law we would identify those changes in the explanatory memorandum, and there they are. So people who want to see how the law has been changed—and the changes are fairly minimal, but necessary—in connection with this exercise, can identify them.

There was also the question as to whether, after this exercise, a comprehensive forum to continue to review taxation policy would be maintained. I think that the committee, generally, came down on the side of accepting—as I accept absolutely—the responsibility, the right and prerogative of governments to determine taxation policy. Certainly, you take advice, but you do not give that responsibility to others. That is the responsibility of government, it stays with government and it should rest with government, whatever government that happens to be.

There was also the question of whether a parliamentary committee should give consideration to emerging tax policy. We did not pursue that question too far. I understand that that is a matter which has still to be resolved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

The sixth question was the one that I referred to before: for whom is a tax act written? People will say that it is written for taxpayers. Of course it is not, and never has been. It is written for the tax professionals and the courts. Most income earning taxpaying citizens would never refer to the tax act itself. Although, as I say, with the restated, rewritten, simplified version, more of them may be encouraged to do so. So we accept, of course, that it is not necessarily written for taxpayers. But we accept, as well—as did Mr Nolan and his team—that one of the purposes of this was to simplify the act to ensure that people with a reasonable level of education and understanding who wanted to refer to it would be able to understand what it said.

Anyone who has referred to the old tax act—even the professionals—did not understand what that said in many cases. The degree of litigation and the costs of compliance that I have referred to indicate some of the great difficulties associated with it. There was also a problem of whether some of the rulings and determinations of the tax department in responding to particular tax questions and issues and problems should have been incorporated. We generally came down on the side of believing that that should not happen. There were some cases where it did, and I have no particular argument or concern about that at all.

I want to take this opportunity, also, to endorse a proposition by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that it review the unworkable and complex sections of tax law. I am not a member in this parliament of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts so I appreciated enormously the privilege of being associated with this exercise during the previous parliament. In conclusion, I would prefer the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to undertake an examination of the possible general tax framework which may be available to us. I refer to the point that I was making before: it is a question of whether we seek to identify income in order to tax it or whether we adopt a different approach.

If the Joint Committee of Public Accounts were to undertake that exercise, what various systems of taxation would be available to us? To highlight what the advantages and disadvantages of that may be, there might be some genuine consensus that would arise from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is one of those committees of the parliament, all of which, to my mind, seek to pursue a bipartisan approach to these questions. This is one area where, if we do not get a bipartisan approach, we will continue to have conflict on a partisan basis. The difficulty associated with that is that it will tend to lock into the system all of those problems, complexities, ambiguities, uncertainties and contradictions which have been in the system from day one and which no amount of rewriting of the tax act will necessarily be able to overcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be relatively brief today. We are here to consider three particular bills—the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996, the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 and the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996—which essentially are part of the commencement, in a legislative sense, of the process of moving to restructure and rewrite the taxation law of this country, particularly the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with interest that there are representatives of the tax law improvement project in the gallery, and I would certainly like to take this opportunity to congratulate them on the work that they have done and the work that they will continue to do, I suspect, for some years to come. Most certainly, this particular activity is bigger than Ben Hur. It is a huge task, and there are still an awful lot of bridges to be crossed until it is completed.

As I mentioned, there are three acts: the assessment bill, which actually proposes to replace major sections of the existing legislation; the consequential amendment bills, which will amend other pieces of Commonwealth legislation that contain references to the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936, to ensure consistency; and the transitional provisions bill, which will explain how the assessment bill will commence to apply. The legislation as it stands is based predominantly on legislation which came through under the previous government. The tax law improvement project is an initiative of the government that I was proud to be a member of in the last parliament.

Certainly, though, the fact that we are here today in a situation where there is bipartisan support for these bills shows that there is an understanding across the parliamentary and political scene in this country that there was a need for major changes. The previous speaker, my friend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), has gone into some of the examples of just how ridiculous the existing legislation is. Vast changes need to occur, and with some haste.

As has also been mentioned, the Joint Committee on Public Accounts considered this matter in the previous parliament and then again at the commencement of this parliament. The committee came down with a report recently, after quite a number of public hearings and taking submissions on the issues of the legislation and what it is proposing. It is fair to say that there was a range of concerns from practitioners in the field about aspects of the legislation. Certainly, we endeavoured to traverse a number of technical issues which came up on those occasions, and I think that a reasonable job was done.

Beyond that, the biggest issue which came up—and which I am pleased to see that the government has taken into account—is the issue of retrospectivity. There was widespread concern through that consultation process that this legislation ought not be retrospective. There were arguments on both sides. I have some sympathy with both. The argument that was put by those favouring the date as it was proposed in the original draft legislation, which would have been 1 July 1996, was certainly more about creating a shock. The one thing I would like to stress today is the fact that the accounting and taxation industry has to grapple with this legislation now, not in 12 months time. They have to get to the guts of it right now, because the situation is that although this is a simplification bill there are, in effect, major changes to the operation of taxation law.

The fact is that there are accounting practitioners who have no idea what is really in this legislation—and that was explained to us through the consultation process of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I accept the argument that they should and I accept the argument that they have to. But the fact was, and is, that they do not really understand the detail of what is coming through, and they have to come to grips with it quickly. There is a set date in this legislation—the middle of next year. That signals very clearly that it will be coming into effect in the very near future and people had better come to grips with it or they are going to have real difficulties in the transitional process. The rest of these bills largely is technical amendments, most of them taking into account the question of the change of dates.

There are a couple of issues I would like to touch on briefly which were also part of the considerations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. They were not necessarily taken up in this legislation but relate to it very significantly. For example, there is the question of a revenue committee. The previous speaker, the member for Charlton, mentioned that the JCPA had not addressed that issue. I think it is fair to say that it has, to a greater extent, in its final report.
The situation as the committee saw it is stated in recommendation 11 of the report which says:
The Government should provide sufficient additional resources to allow either:

(a) the Joint Committee of Public Account to oversight the processes for resolving the minor tax policy simplification issues that are highlighted by the Tax Law Improvement Project and make recommendations to government; or

(b) the establishment of a Joint Standing Committee on Revenue with terms of reference and powers to review all matters in relation to Commonwealth revenue and to make recommendations to government; or

(c) the establishment of a joint select committee with terms of reference and powers to assess the minor tax policy simplification issues referred to it by Parliament and to make recommendations to government.

If I could paraphrase one of the major concerns expressed through the consultation process from a range of industry representatives it was that, as the legislation comes into operation and as difficulties are discovered—as they will be, as has been conceded by all sides—how quickly would those sorts of issues be addressed. The point was made that if, for example, it was something that cost the government revenue, the odds were that action would be swift and brutal; if the situation was the reverse of that, in the fullness of time it might require a full consideration of the issues ad nauseam.

The hope is—and it is certainly the hope of the committee—that those matters can be addressed quickly, effectively and efficiently to meet the concerns of the industry. I think that is also the wish of people in the TLIP. But from what I have seen of this place in the years I have been here, I think there need to be some very formal processes to address those matters, otherwise things may not get addressed. On the question of options, the committee put down three variations on the theme that the government could pick up and I think there is plenty of room there for the government to decide on what they see as the best option. I have my own preference, but I would say that any of the options mentioned certainly give a firm basis for pursuing the matter in the future.
Another issue of concern related to the question on technical errors. Recommendation 9 of the report says:

Technical errors in the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 should be corrected as a matter of priority. The corrections should either be incorporated in future instalments of the legislation to replace the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 or be dealt with as part of the technical corrections process recently put in place by the Australian Taxation Office, whichever process is quicker. Furthermore, technical amendments legislation should become the regular vehicle for making technical corrections to tax law.

Again, the arguments I have put regarding the previous issue of a revenue committee of some sort are relevant here: action is needed on changes as they are discovered and variations that need to be done must be acted upon quickly.

Another issue which came up was the question of rulings. The nature of the taxation system as it stands is that so much of the detail is in the actual legislation, but so much more detail in many respects is actually contained in rulings done by the Commissioner of Taxation. Recommendation 2 of the report says:

BREAK.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation and the major tax bodies (through the National Tax Liaison Group) should agree, as a matter of urgency, to a process and timetable for rewriting existing Public Rulings affected by the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 and subsequent legislation. The process and priority to be given to rewriting individual Rulings should be determined by the end of 1996 and be made publicly available. The public statement should also include a completion date for the process of rewriting the Rulings.
I understand that there may have been some developments with respect to this. I have not seen any details. What I would say is that that is of particular urgency.

Another issue that was raised with us through this process is the question of legislation and rulings. Essentially, if both are not fixed, then in many respects, nothing is fixed. Therefore, that action is also crucial and further advancements need to be made on that basis.

Another issue that I will mention is the question of the actual savings associated with this legislation. An argument that was put to us was that there were significant savings to be made through the process of this legislation. However, when debate occurred, there was some difficulty in terms of quantifying the actual real value of these changes.

I do not pretend to be a taxation expert in any way, shape or form, but when you see something go from one size down to another size, you tend to think—at least in a visual sense—that there is an improvement. From looking at some of the detail there—for example, looking at some of the points that were made by the member for Charlton—one tends to think there will be substantial savings over time in terms of the time taken to actually apply the legislation. Certainly, it is agreed that, in the short term, in the first couple of years while practitioners are becoming accustomed to the new system, and as the system is being progressively introduced, there will be difficulties and additional costs. I think that everyone accepts that that is necessary in order to get a better long‐term system.

However, one recommendation which the JCPA put forward was that the Australian Taxation Office should undertake or assist with further research attempting to quantify the costs of tax compliance in Australia. Again, I am no expert, but I suspect that the costs are absolutely phenomenal. There is some figure work available on those issues, but certainly the question of what these changes will do, in terms of reducing and minimising that cost, is uncertain at best. I suspect that when that work is done, we will find that it is quite significant. But I urge for that work to be done because the one thing that we certainly need to try to ensure with legislation going through this place is an element of accountability. And that accountability relates not only to the question of conflicts of interest, nor to practical applications and outcomes, but it is also a question of dollars and of real effect. If we cannot quantify what the real effect of a change is, then we have got to really question just how much value there is in that change. On this occasion, I think that there is value. I certainly support the legislation and wish it a speedy passage through both houses of the parliament. But I think we also ought to be able, for our own sake, and for the ATO's sake, to actually say, `This is what it is worth.'

As I mentioned earlier, this legislation and the whole process through the taxation law improvement project is, as the member of Charlton said, not a question of actual improvement, but of simplification. That simplification is an improvement in terms of the way the law will be applied. I will not go into a number of arguments about the question of what taxation law we should actually have, although I would concur in many respects with the previous speaker about the nature of the sort of taxation system we should have. But I would also say that taxation law debate is similar, in many respects, to discussions that I have had on religion. It is very easy to have very long and involved arguments and it is often confusing. In the end it seems to come down sometimes to articles of faith. I reserve the right to have my own articles of faith, as I am sure others do. I wish the legislation a speedy passage. I congratulate those involved in getting it together. I wish them all the very best in the future in terms of dealing with the rest of this process. I do not envy them. I do not wish to join them, but I have a feeling that if I am still in the JCPA, I am going to have a look at what they have done. I commend the legislation to the House for a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the three bills which are being debated cognately, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 contains by far the most important measures, the others containing, as their titles suggest, transitional provisions and consequential amendments. All three bills were introduced into the House by Mr Miles, the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister on 19 June. Subsequently, the government took the unusually wise step of referring the legislation to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and I have already recorded my compliments to its chairman, members and staff for the work they did.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax law improvement project was first announced by the former Labor government in December 1993, with the object of rewriting the income tax laws in simple language. The project actually got started on 1 July 1994 and was—and, I understand, still is—expected to be completed after three years, by the end of financial year 1997. The project has a consultative committee of 14 members made up of representatives of accounting and legal firms, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Corporate Tax Association, the National Farmers Federation and the Taxation Institute of Australia. There are also a couple of representatives from other private sector sources.

The announcement of the project followed a recommendation made in November 1993 by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts along the lines that the then government should establish a broadly based task force to redraft the principal income tax act. The project team has also released a broad framework. It makes clear that it is not about reforming the tax system or rewriting tax policy. The focus is on administrative rules that are overly complex, unnecessary or out of date in today's realities. However, the framework also made it clear that, when redrafting, the project team may come across provisions where the meaning is unclear. Those cases, it was anticipated, might require the government to clarify the policy so that the law itself can be more clearly written.

The objectives of the then government—and, as far as I know, of the present government—include shorter, clearer, simpler and more readable text than we find in present law. This is to be achieved by restructuring, renumbering and rewriting the legislation, as has already been indicated by previous speakers. One aim is to reduce compliance costs by rewriting the principal act and other tax laws, to render them easier to understand. These objectives cannot be met until early in the next century, we are told, although I hope that there will be some improvement on that timetable.

The major shortcoming with this whole exercise has been the narrowness of the review. Complex tax policy issues which need to be addressed to achieve major simplification of the tax system have been totally ignored—in this bill, anyway—with the emphasis of this project resting 100 per cent on using plain English and adopting a simple legislative structure. This is to be commended but, as I have to go on and outline, it goes nowhere near far enough. The rewriting of the income tax laws will be completed over an extended time, so there are more bills to follow these and the rewritten substantiation rules, which have already been passed by the parliament. The rewritten income tax law will eventually replace the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

As I have stated in this place on many occasions, there is no doubt whatsoever that the tax system needs simplifying. Compliance costs have become exorbitant. They are at the top end of the scale in the Western world. This is attributable both to policies which underlie our tax laws and, in many cases, to the attitude of the Australian Taxation Office. In a Business Review Weekly article entitled `The war on paperwork', published on 12 February of this year, Ms Lucinda Schmidt said:
As well as massive restructuring of the tax system, accountants suggest that halving the paper burden requires radical change in the Tax Office's attitude.

They argue that much of the paperwork is generated by a tax office driven by Treasury to squeeze every last dollar from the business community, while operating on the assumption that most taxpayers are keen to avoid tax.

The actions and performance of the Australian Taxation Office, in so many areas, bears this out. It seems that the ATO is intent on coming up on occasions with the most ridiculous amendments and rulings, simply to squeeze the maximum amount of revenue out of the economy.

In the 22 July edition of Business Review Weekly, a fringe benefits tax ruling is discussed whereby employers have to pay fringe benefits tax on food and drink consumed by an employee who attends work related entertainment provided by a customer. The rationale of the fringe benefits tax was always to stop employers providing non‐cash benefits, such as family holidays, children's school fees, company cars and the like, as part of an employee's overall remuneration package. How is that particular ruling furthering such an objective? The answer is that it is not, of course. It is administrative bloody‐mindedness. There is no public benefit from such a measure and it certainly would not survive any cost‐benefit analysis. It is penny pinching gone mad. But it is only one example.
Another is raised by Tony Lovett, an accountant, in the February BRW article, which reported as follows:
Lovett says that FBT has a basic flaw: it taxes the employer, not the employee who gets the benefit.
And he questions the way the Commissioner sometimes interprets the law.
As an example of a taxpayer being allegedly unfairly treated, Lovett cites one of his clients, a husband and wife company.
The husband made an interest free loan to the company of $150,000 and, in turn, the company lent $40,000 to the wife.
"The Commissioner is insisting that it is an employee loan and FBT is payable.
Any one can see that is not the case, and huge compliance costs are being incurred over a fight that he has no chance of winning.
It is farcical.
Where's the rort?
How is the company robbing the tax revenue?"
Clearly the time is right for the tax office to lift its game and stop muddying tax policy waters. But concurrent to such a need is that the tax system not only be simplified but also be reformed.

BREAK.PARA: Many people hoped that, with the election of a coalition government, the scope of the tax law improvement project would be widened beyond mere simplification by the use of plain English and a new numbering system. However, it appears that the project will not be significantly widened. In another article in Business Review Weekly, the edition of 17 June this year, Ms Schmidt wrote:
The Minister responsible for the project, Assistant Treasurer Jim Short, has made it clear that he sees the TLIP as an important part of the government's overall plan for simplifying tax laws.
He also says he wants the project to do more than simply rewrite existing law in plain English; he suggests the project must also consider anomalies and inconsistencies in the present law.
It is hard to believe that what we have so far seen and heard is indicative of a government which is content only to tinker around the edges. Ms Lucinda Schmidt goes on to say that some tax advisers:
. . . fear the TLIP will plod on and waste taxpayers' money tinkering around with wording, while fundamental changes are being drafted by other bodies.

I doubt that we will see any radical change, but that is exactly what we require. Radical change is essential if the tax system is to be simplified and the cost of compliance is to be reduced significantly.

It might be useful at this stage to go over the origins of this. The project was established by the Keating government on 1 July 1994, following consistent ongoing criticism from legal and accounting bodies of delays in simplification of tax legislation. It appears that the then government's decision to establish the project was also driven by a belief that the rewrite of our complex tax legislation would result in a significant reduction in compliance costs.

This would have been welcome news to the proprietors of as many as 929,339 Australian small businesses, which have been weighed down by the burgeoning cost of tax compliance. Some 26 months later, I pose a rhetorical question to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or perhaps to the parliamentary secretary at the table: what improvements have been enjoyed by the private sector as a result of the recommendations of the project team? The answer is none.

Admittedly, the project team still has another 10 months to continue its deliberations, but the fact is that there are fundamental flaws in its charter which leave little room for optimism in the small business community. The project team has yet to publish its statement of criteria for determination of what is an acceptable level of complexity in the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is a given that some degree of complication goes hand in hand with income tax. However, how can this team work towards simplifying income tax legislation if no valid or worthwhile attempt has been made to identify how complex it must be in the first place?

One of the benefits of tax simplification done well will be certainty. As tax law becomes more confusing, the small business proprietors in this country are more likely to employ the services of tax professionals to advise them of their obligations. However, this advice, as we all know, comes at great expense to those proprietors at a time when they are still recovering from unnecessary cashflow problems caused by the former Labor government's taxing and regulatory regimes. Therefore, it is unlikely that small business owners will favour activities where the profit outcome is more predictable. Economic neutrality is being jeopardised by tax complexity.

Another shortcoming of the project team's agenda is its failure to identify who the targeted readership of the simplified legislation is. The ordinary taxpayer—which includes the proprietor of a small business—was identified initially as being the reader in the team's first two information papers. Hence, we would have expected that the new legislation would be written in the language of the layman. Such a non-elitist approach would actually mean more people would understand their tax rights and obligations. Wouldn't that be a change!

They would also be able to work out more easily what tax they are required to pay, saving time and money for reinvestment and for productive effort. These savings, coupled with those gained from a reduction in the uplift factor, might then enable the small business community in Australia to employ more productive staff. However, by late 1994 the project team had decided it was more practical to focus on tax professionals than on individuals, resulting in a very different rewrite of the tax legislation.

This poses the question, Mr Deputy Speaker: what is the point of replacing existing legislation which is targeted towards professional readership with new legislation also aimed at tax professionals. If the present Howard government is truly committed to reducing the costs to small businesses in complying with tax laws and business regulations, what does it plan to do to modify and implement the tax law simplification project? I submit that the determination of the readership of the new laws and the definition of complexity of tax compliance need to be addressed immediately.

The coalition knows that the primary goals of tax simplification should be to make the law easier to understand, reduce the cost of compliance and bring logic and rationality to the tax system. Labor totally failed to understand this, though I still believe the coalition, in its second term, might get around to making some radical changes, but we will have to wait and see.

The coalition, nevertheless, must be prepared to examine tax policy issues which need to be rectified if the system is to be simplified. Policy is at the heart of much of the complexity, and all the simplification effort in the world will not eradicate complexity unless policy is tackled. A good start in this direction would be to allow the TLIP to expand into policy areas. A recent report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts urged the government to comprehensively review tax policy, focusing not only on tax legislation, but also on the administrative systems underpinning it. The committee ended its report to the parliament by noting that:
Only after such a review can compliance costs come down significantly. When that occurs, the burden on taxpayers and tax administrators should ease, and the result lead to a more efficient economy.
Only time will tell if the coalition has the foresight and the resolution to undertake the tax reform job properly.

Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (11.08 a.m.)—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise to continue some discussion on this bill and to point out a few things concerning comments made by speakers in the Main Committee this morning.

The first thing to say about this is that certainly modern business activity is complex and it would be raising unrealistic expectations to the point of naivety to hope for our tax laws to become truly simple. The task which has been undertaken here is an important task; it has been going on now for a considerable time. The taxation system has to meet the fundamental objective of raising revenue for the nation against the background of the very sophisticated commercial and social environment in Australia, as well as our competitive situation in the rest of the world.

The desire for simplicity also has to be assessed against the other important tax design principles of equity and efficiency. Often these things compete with each other and compromises have to be made. But the government believes that the taxation system carries too high a compliance cost for the business community. I know that the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is indicating that nothing of practical benefit has come out of the work to date—I think I am summarising him reasonably accurately. I think that there does have to be some credit given to the fact that, in this rewrite, the simplification of language is important and, as time goes on, I think that that will bring benefits overall. In that regard, it is interesting to note what the Joint Committee of Public Accounts had to say—and I just want to mention two or three of its quotes in this regard:
The committee believes that the language of the 1996 bill and particularly the core and general provision should be understood by all those who need to read it.
It also states:
The bills represent a significant improvement over the current law. They are widely regarded as being far easier to read and understand than the legislation they will replace.

Benefits will come from having a simpler structure and language which is simpler to read. Hopefully, as time goes on, this will benefit business people in the community. So I disagree to a certain extent with the statement of the member for Curtin that no benefits will come from this. I believe they will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that there had been no benefits after 26 months.
—Yes, that is true. I agree with what the member for Curtin says. So I think we need to look to what benefits can flow in the future.

BREAK.PARA: The complexity of the Income Tax Assessment Act undoubtedly contributes greatly to the costs of business. If we can reduce excessive compliance costs in the tax system, we will reduce the cost of doing business, which will lead to higher productivity and increased competitiveness and will have positive impacts on economic growth and employment. This is why this bill is an important element in simplifying the tax laws and increasing certainty and confidence in the tax system.

The first stage in rewriting the law creates the structure for a new income tax assessment act to replace the 60‐year‐old law that is long past its use‐by date. The new legislation is presented in plain language with a new numbering system capable of accommodating expansion in the years ahead. It uses modern design and layout techniques to assist access and comprehension.

I am grateful to the honourable members who have participated in this debate in a positive way in considering the issues involved. The one‐year deferral in the commencement date will allow the community to prepare on the basis of a definite starting date, with adequate time for the training and preparation of businesses that tax professionals and the Taxation Office will need.

A major focus of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in considering the bill in its report No. 345 was how policy review should be handled. Critics have said that the rewrite project is too narrowly focused and that opportunities for important tax law reform are not being taken. The JCPA understood that combining tax policy review with such a vast task as rewriting the whole of the Income Tax Assessment Act would have led to the project getting bogged down and not being completed within an acceptable time frame.

I think all the speakers here have alluded to the dichotomy between doing a rewrite of the tax act to make it simpler and get a better structure, and the wider policy issues for Australia in regard to taxation. The committee has suggested that a committee of the parliament—perhaps the JCPA itself—might be given the task of addressing the minor tax policy simplification issues that are highlighted in the processes of the project. This raises a range of issues, including resourcing and process matters, and the government is deciding on its response.

In the meantime, putting the law on a decent basis in terms of structure, language and comprehension is itself a major and necessary improvement which sets up a legislative platform from which further review can be undertaken with greater efficiency than the present excessively complex laws would allow.

On behalf of the government, I wish to thank the people who participated in the work. I know that a number of those people are here this morning. To a certain extent, there has been a lot of tedium in doing this, but we do appreciate the work. I am sure that a lot of people working in the taxation framework within the country and trying to read, interpret and have a good understanding of what the taxation laws mean, will appreciate the hard work which has been done by both the government and non‐government officials on this project. I thank you very much for that and, in particular, I thank Brian Nolan.

We can sum up the achievements reflected in the bill as making significant progress towards the fundamental goal of rewriting the tax law in plain and economical language for the benefit of the community. We in this place, and people who are writing laws, should always be mindful that really we are here to benefit the Australian community. This project is about that, and certainly some of the language which I have read makes it much easier already for me to understand the tax law.

The new structure has met with broad approval, as have many user‐friendly features incorporated to assist readers, especially tax practitioners, on whose advice business relies in tax matters. There has been strong approval of the structural design and the new numbering system. Many quite innovative design features have been included to improve communication of the law. These are already having an impact on wider Commonwealth legislative drafting practice and are something of a trailblazer for improvement of Commonwealth law generally. The bill makes a substantial number of minor rule changes, which remove unnecessary compliance barriers, and provide simplifications designed to bring the law into closer alignment with administrative and commercial practices.

One of the factors that have assisted the formulation of these improvements is the extensive consultation that has been undertaken, in the development stages of the drafting, with industry focus groups, tax professionals and more general audiences. The ideas and suggestions flowing from these processes have greatly enriched the quality of the bill. The government believes these processes of consultation and review allow differences to be aired openly and frankly, contributing markedly to the end product.

This bill marks the completion of a major stage in the progressive delivery of improved tax law. The second stage is expected to be reached by the end of the year, when another substantial bill should be ready for introduction into the parliament, containing rewrites of very substantial components of the law, to be inserted in the new structure. A preliminary draft revision of capital gains tax should also be completed for public comment around that time.

At this point, I would like to indicate also that we will be moving a number of amendments on behalf of the government in due course, and at this stage I would just like to go through some details in that regard. For the convenience of members, the amendments have been brought together in three packages. The first package will defer the commencement date of the bills. The second package will introduce streamlined arrangements for identifying who owns the shares of certain companies. The third package will make a number of miscellaneous minor changes to the bills.

In the first package, the amendments will defer the date of commencement of the bills by 12 months, to 1 July 1997. This means that the bills will start to apply in the 1997‐98 income year. This later date will allow more time for a smooth transition to the new law. The Assistant Treasurer announced this measure in his response to the report by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on bills, which was tabled in the House on 22 August. The amendments broadly accord with the recommendations of the joint committee, which proposed a starting date from the income year following royal assent. However, the community needs to be able to plan on the basis of a definite starting date. Of course, if the bills are enacted prior to 1 July 1997, the starting date will give effect exactly to the committee's recommendations.

Amendments T1 to T30 of the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 are those tracing the ownership of listed public companies. These amendments will provide, in the rewritten losses provisions, streamlined rules for listed public companies to establish who owns their shares. The amendments were announced by the Assistant Treasurer in his response to the joint committee's report. The new rules are a major compliance cost breakthrough; they will provide more certainty and a far simpler method for establishing share ownership. Companies need to maintain continuity of ownership to deduct tax losses. For listed public companies, tracing through nominee companies and interposed entities to identify very large numbers of individual beneficial owners can impose a significant evidentiary burden.

The new rules build on administrative arrangements put in place by the Commissioner of Taxation. There are two features to the new rules. Firstly, companies will no longer be required to trace ownership on an ongoing basis. Instead, companies will only be required to trace ownership if there has been abnormal trading in its shares. There will be one exception, the case of prior year losses, where the ownership must also be traced at the end of each year until the loss is recouped. This is a significant concession. The existing rules require testing at all times during the year of the loss and the year the loss is recouped.

Secondly, small shareholdings of less than one per cent will be aggregated, and a national shareholder will be taken to own that pool of shares. Using established rules in the Corporations Law, large, indirect shareholdings held in small parcels of shares will be excluded from the pool. As well, safeguards will ensure that the rules do not operate to defeat the purpose of the continuity of the beneficial ownership test. Additionally, shares held by complying approved deposit funds, complying superannuation funds, mutual life companies and certain other companies with similar characteristics will be taken to be the beneficial owner of those shares. This will relieve the obligation to trace beneficial ownership of those shares.

As with all the amendments being moved by the government, these improvements to the law will apply from the 1997‐98 income year. These are miscellaneous changes. The third package of amendments will make a number of minor technical changes to the bills. These changes do not involve any change in policy and are mainly designed to correct drafting errors and omissions and to ensure that the new law accurately rewrites the existing law. Each of the amendments is explained in more detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum accompanying these amendments. I commend the amendments and the bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
