PARA.TAB: This Subdivision modifies how the ownership tests are applied to the *listed public company (the head company ) if the company has:

TAB.TAB: (a) *voting shareholdings of less than 1%; or
(b) *dividend shareholdings of less than 1%; or
(c) *capital shareholdings of less than 1%.

PARA.TAB: For the ownership tests: see sections 166‐150, 166‐155 and 166-160.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐225 Shareholdings of less than 1% in an interposed listed public company

PARA.TAB: (1) This Subdivision also modifies how the ownership tests are applied to the *head company if another *listed public company (the interposed company ) meets the conditions in subsections (2) and (3).

TAB.TAB: For the ownership tests: see sections 166‐150, 166‐155 and 166-160.

PARA.TAB: (2) The *interposed company must be interposed between the *head company and persons (none of them companies) who:

TAB.TAB: (a) control (or are able to control) voting power in the head company indirectly through the interposed company; or
(b) have the right to receive, for their own benefit and *indirectly through the interposed company, any *dividends the head company may pay; or
(c) have the right to receive, for their own benefit and *indirectly through the interposed company, any distributions of capital of the head company.

PARA.TAB: (3) The *interposed company must have:

TAB.TAB: (a) *voting shareholdings of less than 1%; or
(b) *dividend shareholdings of less than 1%; or
(c) *capital shareholdings of less than 1%.
Notional shareholder of the head company

PARA.TAB: (1) The ownership tests in sections 166‐150, 166‐155 and 166‐160 are applied to the *head company as if, at the *ownership test time, a single notional entity (the notional shareholder ):

TAB.TAB: (a) directly controlled the voting power in the head company that is carried by each *voting shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time; and
(b) had the right to receive, for its own benefit and directly:
(i) any *dividends the head company may pay in respect of each *dividend shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time; and
(ii) any distributions of capital of the head company in respect of each *capital shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time; and
(c) were a person (other than a company).
Notional shareholder of the interposed company

PARA.TAB: (2) The tests are also applied to the *head company as if, at the *ownership test time, for each *interposed company, a different single notional entity (the notional shareholder ):

TAB.TAB: (a) directly controlled the voting power in the interposed company that is carried by each *voting shareholding of less than 1% in the interposed company at that time; and
(b) had the right to receive, for its own benefit and directly:
(i) any *dividends the interposed company may pay in respect of each *dividend shareholding of less than 1% in the interposed company at that time; and
(ii) any distributions of capital of the interposed company in respect of each *capital shareholding of less than 1% in the interposed company at that time; and
(c) were a person (other than a company).
Persons who actually control or have rights are taken not to

PARA.TAB: (3) The tests are also applied to the *head company as if, at the *ownership test time:

TAB.TAB: (a) the persons (other than companies) who control (or are able to control) the voting power in the head company or interposed company (whether directly, or indirectly through one or more interposed entities) that is carried by each *voting shareholding of less than 1% in the company had not had that control; and
(b) the persons (other than companies) who have the right to receive for their own benefit (whether directly, or *indirectly through one or more interposed entities):
(i) any *dividends that the head company or interposed company may pay in respect of each *dividend shareholding of less than 1% in the company; and
(ii) any distributions of capital of the head company or interposed company in respect of each *capital shareholding of less than 1% in the company;
had not had that right.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐235 Notional shareholder taken to have minimum voting control, dividend rights and capital rights

TAB.TAB: Minimum control of voting power

PARA.TAB: (1) If the *ownership test time is after the start of the *test period and:

TAB.TAB: . the voting power in the *head company or *interposed company that the *notional shareholder controls at that time;
is greater than:
. the voting power in the company that the notional shareholder controlled at the start of that period;
the notional shareholder is taken to control voting power in the company at that time only to the extent that it controlled it at the start of that period.
Minimum percentage of rights to dividends and capital

PARA.TAB: (2) If the *ownership test time is after the start of the *test period and:

TAB.TAB: . the percentage of the *dividends or distributions of capital of the *head company or *interposed company that the *notional shareholder has the right to receive at that time;
is greater than:
. the percentage (the lower percentage ) of the dividends or distributions of capital of the company that the notional shareholder had the right to receive at the start of that period;
the notional shareholder is taken to have the right to receive the lower percentage of the dividends or distributions of capital at that time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐240 Voting, dividend and capital shareholding of less than 1%

EMPHASIS.TAB: Meaning of voting shareholding of less than 1%

PARA.TAB: (1) If all the *shares in the *head company or *interposed company of which an entity is the registered holder at the *ownership test time carry (between them) less than 1% of the voting power in the company, those shares (except shares that are *part of a substantial shareholding) constitute a voting shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Meaning of dividend shareholding of less than 1%

PARA.TAB: (2) If all the *shares in the *head company or *interposed company of which an entity is the registered holder at the *ownership test time carry (between them) the right to receive less than 1% of any *dividends that the company may pay, those shares (except shares that are *part of a substantial shareholding) constitute a dividend shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Meaning of capital shareholding of less than 1%

PARA.TAB: (3) If all the *shares in the *head company or *interposed company of which an entity is the registered holder at the *ownership test time carry (between them) the right to receive less than 1% of any distribution of capital of the company, those shares (except shares that are *part of a substantial shareholding) constitute a capital shareholding of less than 1% in the company at that time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐245 Shares that are part of a substantial shareholding

PARA.TAB: (1) *Shares in a company begin to be part of a substantial shareholding of a person when the person gives the company:

TAB.TAB: (a) a notice under section 709 of the Corporations Law from which it appears that the person or an associate (within the meaning of that section) had a *relevant interest in the shares as at the day when the person became a substantial shareholder in the company; or

(b) a notice under section 710 of the Corporations Law from which it appears that the person or an associate (within the meaning of that section) had a *relevant interest in the shares after the change in relevant interests because of which the notice had to be given;
whichever happens first.

PARA.TAB: (2) The *shares stop being part of the substantial shareholding when the person gives the company:

TAB.TAB: (a) a notice under section 710 of the Corporations Law from which it appears that neither the person nor an associate (within the meaning of that section) had a *relevant interest in the shares after the change in relevant interests because of which the notice had to be given; or
(b) a notice under section 711 of the Corporations Law from which it appears that the person has stopped being a substantial shareholder in the company;
whichever happens first.

PARA.EMPHASIS: When the rules in this Subdivision do not apply
166‐250 Limit on listed public company splitting its shares into different classes

PARA.TAB: This Subdivision does not apply unless, at the *ownership test time, all the *voting shares in the *head company carry (between them):

TAB.TAB: (a) the right to receive more than 75% of any *dividends the head company may pay; and
(b) the right to receive more than 75% of any distributions of capital of the head company.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐255 If listed public company would not have otherwise passed the ownership tests

PARA.TAB: This Subdivision does not apply for the purposes of section 166‐5 or 166‐20 if the Commissioner considers it reasonable to assume that the *head company would not meet the conditions in that section if it were not for the rules in this Subdivision.
Note: The conditions in sections 166‐5 and 166‐20 require the listed public company to maintain the same owners at each ownership test time during the test period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subdivision 166‐G—How to treat interposed superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and special companies

PARA.TAB: Note: The rules in this Subdivision also apply to a company that is a 100% subsidiary of a listed public company: see sections 166‐10 and 166-30.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Special tracing rules for listed public companies

PARA.TAB: 166‐265 When fund or special company is taken to control voting power
166‐270 When fund or special company is taken to have rights to dividends and capital

PARA.EMPHASIS: Special tracing rules for listed public companies
166‐265 When fund or special company is taken to control voting power

PARA.TAB: (1) This section modifies how the ownership test in section 166‐150 (about control of voting) is applied to the *listed public company if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a *superannuation fund, *approved deposit fund or *special company is interposed, at the *ownership test time, between persons (none of them companies) and the listed public company; and

(b) at the ownership test time, those persons control (or are able to control) any of the voting power in the listed public company indirectly through the fund or special company (or through entities including it); and

(c) the fund or special company is a *complying superannuation fund, *complying approved deposit fund or special company at all times during the income year of the listed public company in which the *ownership test time occurs.
If fund or special company has more than 50 members

PARA.TAB: (2) If the fund or *special company has more than 50 *members, the test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, the fund or special company were a person (other than a company) who controlled the voting power in the *listed public company that those persons control (or are able to control).

TAB.TAB: If fund or special company has 50 members or less

PARA.TAB: (3) However, if the fund or *special company has 50 *members or less, the test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, each member were a person (other than a company) who controlled an equal proportion of the voting power in the *listed public company that those persons control (or are able to control).

TAB.TAB: Persons who actually control are taken not to control

PARA.TAB: (4) The test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, the voting power in the *listed public company that those persons control (or are able to control) were not controlled by them (except as provided by subsection (3)).

PARA.EMPHASIS: 166‐270 When fund or special company is taken to have rights to dividends and capital

PARA.TAB: (1) This section modifies how the ownership test in section 166‐155 (about *dividend rights) or 166‐160 (about capital rights) is applied to the *listed public company if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a *superannuation fund, *approved deposit fund or *special company is interposed, at the *ownership test time, between persons (none of them companies) and the listed public company; and
(b) at the ownership test time, those persons have the right to receive for their own benefit, and *indirectly through the fund or special company (or through entities including it):
(i) a percentage of any *dividends that the listed public company may pay; or
(ii) a percentage of any distributions of capital of the listed public company; and

(c) the fund or special company is a *complying superannuation fund, *complying approved deposit fund or special company at all times during the income year of the listed public company in which the *ownership test time occurs.
If fund or special company has more than 50 members

PARA.TAB: (2) If the fund or *special company has more than 50 *members, the test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, the fund or special company were a person (other than a company) who had the right to receive, for the person's own benefit, that percentage of those *dividends or distributions of capital of the *listed public company.

PROCTEXT.PARA: If fund or special company has 50 members or less

PARA.TAB: (3) However, if the fund or *special company has 50 *members or less, the test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, each member were a person (other than a company) who had a right to receive, for the person's own benefit, an equal proportion of those *dividends or distributions of capital.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Persons who actually have the right are taken not to have it

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4)The test is applied as if, at the *ownership test time, the persons (other than companies) who have the right to receive that percentage of those *dividends or distributions of capital did not have that right (except as provided by subsection (3)).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subdivision 960‐H—Abnormal trading in shares or units

PARA.TAB: 960‐220 Meaning of trading
960‐225 Abnormal trading
960‐230 Abnormal trading—5% of shares or units in one transaction
960‐235 Abnormal trading—suspected 5% of shares or units in a series of transactions
960‐240 Abnormal trading—suspected acquisition or merger
960‐245 Abnormal trading—20% of shares or units traded over 60 day period
There is a trading in *shares in a *listed public company, or in units in a unit trust, if there is an issue, redemption or transfer of, or any other dealing in, those shares or units.

(1) There is an abnormal trading in *shares in a *listed public company, or in units in a unit trust, if a *trading in the shares or units is abnormal having regard to all relevant factors, including these:

TAB.TAB: (a) the timing of the trading, when compared with the normal timing for trading in the company's shares or in the trust's units;
(b) the number of shares or units traded, when compared with the normal number of the company's shares, or the trust's units, traded;
(c) any connection between the trading and any other trading in the company's shares or in the trust's units;
(d) any connection between the trading and a *tax loss or other deduction of the company or trust.

PARA.TAB: (2) There may also be an abnormal trading under any of the following provisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 960‐230 Abnormal trading—5% of shares or units in one transaction

TAB.TAB: There is an abnormal trading in *shares in a *listed public company, or in units in a unit trust, if 5% or more of the shares or units are *traded in one transaction.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 960‐235 Abnormal trading—suspected 5% of shares or units in a series of transactions

PARA.TAB: (1) There is an abnormal trading in *shares in a *listed public company, or in units in a unit trust, if the company or trustee knows or reasonably suspects that an entity (or an entity and one or more of the entity's *associates) has acquired (or redeemed) 5% or more of the shares or units in 2 or more transactions and would not have done so if the company or trust did not have a *tax loss or other deduction.

TAB.TAB: Time when abnormal trading happens

PARA.TAB: (2) The *abnormal trading happens at the time of the particular transaction that causes the 5% figure to be exceeded.

TAB.TAB: There is an abnormal trading in *shares in a *listed public company, or in units in a unit trust, if a *trading in those shares or units happens which the company or trustee knows or reasonably suspects is part of an acquisition or merger of the company with another company, or of the trust with another trust.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 960‐245 Abnormal trading—20% of shares or units traded over 60 day period

PARA.TAB: (1) There is an abnormal trading in *shares in a *listed public company or units in a unit trust if more than 20% of the shares or units are *traded during a 60 day period.

TAB.TAB: Time when abnormal trading happens

PARA.TAB: (2) The *abnormal trading happens at the end of the 60 day period concerned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 September, on motion by Mr Brereton:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The seminar on the Australian aid program was an important and timely seminar. I feel that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade should conduct more such seminars. In this regard I am pleased to note that a seminar, reviewing a report that that committee brought down on our relationship with PNG, is planned for early November.

SPEECH.PARA: Few issues in the community generate as much discussion as aid, and I suspect that few issues are as misunderstood or misreported as the whole aid question. Regardless of the misinformation peddled throughout the community, few, I suggest, could argue with the fact that the gap between the rich and the poor in so many countries is continuing to grow. Australia has always had a good record regarding the question of aid and I hope that it will continue. Despite our living in a technologically advanced age, there is a persistence of poverty throughout the world.

As was said during the seminar by a representative of AusAid, describing the development needs of the world, approximately 800 million to 1.3 billion live in absolute poverty in the world today. About one billion people do not have access to basic health services, 1.3 billion do not have access to safe water and two billion do not have access to sanitation services. Approximately 30 per cent of land in Africa is affected by significant degradation, as is about 20 per cent of land in Asia. There are about 54 million refugees and displaced persons in the world today. To add to that list of needs, the vice‐president of the World Bank indicated that the unmet infrastructure needs in East Asia alone require $1.9 trillion in investment over the decade.

Poverty is not only persistent, but in the post‐Cold War world, it is a growing phenomenon giving greater polarisation between the rich and poor. A sobering statistic is that 89 countries are worse off today than they were 10 years ago, and 1.6 billion people are worse off than they were 15 years ago. Infant mortality is rising. Twenty‐one per cent of the world's population saw their share of global income decline from 2.3 to 1.4 per cent over the last 30 years.

Perhaps the most dramatic statistic presented at the seminar was that the assets of the world's 358 billionaires exceed the combined annual incomes of countries with 45 per cent of the world's population. That is something that we should consider, and I am particularly pleased that you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker—not only because I should be there and you were kind enough to relieve me—as I know that you would have a particular interest in that statistic with your interest in poverty reduction throughout the world. The income of the 358 billionaires of the world exceeds the combined annual income of countries with 45 per cent of the world's population.

To hear many members of the general public talk about aid, and indeed some members in this place, one would think that Australia was one of those 89 countries that are worse off today than they were 10 years ago. Like many members, I hear ill‐informed comments that Australia is heading for Third World status. When people come up to me or write letters to my electorate and say that Australia is heading for Third World status, my usual response to them is to ask when they were last in a Third World country. Regardless of what problems we might have in this country, and I sometimes think, I must say, that the problems in this country are never as great as many imagine, these problems pale into insignificance with the problems of Third World countries. I suggest that most Third World countries would readily exchange their problems for ours. As such, we have a responsibility and a duty to continue aid—a moral as well as a practical responsibility.

Having said that, when large amounts of aid are given, I believe it is our right to ensure that it goes for the purpose granted. That is, I have been in favour of giving to some of the international organisations untied aid, but I think that when we give aid on a one‐to‐one basis with a country, we have a right to say where it should go. I remember some years ago I was a member of the committee that brought down the report on our relationship with PNG. Having visited that country with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and other people, I was very strongly for the recommendations in that report that the bulk of our aid to PNG should go from untied to tied. I think that there was no dissent on that committee. Everyone who was on that committee and who brought down that report felt that that should be. I know that since that time there has been some discussion with officials from PNG earlier this year about whether the aid that we give to PNG should go back to being untied. Considering the amount of aid—and PNG receives the largest amount of Australian aid—I think we have struck the right balance of it being tied. It should go into specific projects that not only we have an interest in, but also the PNG people have an interest in. Nothing since that time has led me to doubt that it was a correct decision that we made.

Having said that, I was very disappointed in the recent budget to see cuts to aid, especially the cuts in the area of population programs. I could better understand it, even if I could not support the issue, if the decision was not made to ensure the support of Senator Harradine over a completely unrelated matter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.36 a.m. to 11.49 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as I was saying, population programs are far too important to be used as a bargaining ploy to obtain a vote in the Australian Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has cut $3.5 million in the foreign aid budget for family planning. Given the population problems of the world, so well documented, and given the fact that over recent years there have been international conferences dealing with the population issue—especially the Cairo Population Conference, and indeed later this year there will be the Rome Food Conference—how can this government justify a cut of $3.5 million in the foreign aid budget for family planning and hold its head up in international forums throughout the world?

The government has slashed funding by $2 million to the United Nations Population Fund, the one coordinating body in the world taking the global approach to this problem. The government has also cut $525,000 to the Population Council and $125,000 to the International Union for the Scientific Study of Population. The International Planned Parenthood Federation has had its grant cut by $1.5 million. Indeed, it was halved.

It has been revealed that earlier this year in the consideration of the budget, Senator Harradine met with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, urging this raft of slashes. Obviously, with the senator's support in mind, the Minister, who really does know better, agreed to his request and the results are there for all to see.

It is a backward step of unbelievable proportions, but we have made this move. We are sending all the wrong messages to the United Nations and to our neighbours. The individual cuts regarding population programs to our Pacific Island neighbours, where we should be taking a leadership role in budgetary terms, are not great, but the impact on programs for countries such as Fiji, Samoa, and other Pacific Island nations will be devastating.

In many cases, we have been generous to these countries. The US has, in recent years, also cut aid to population programs in this part of the world. So what sort of a message are the world's industrialised countries sending to the Third World?

In the report on the conference the document says that it was largely a summary of the day's discussion. It did not seek to come to definite conclusions although the committee did include a number of recommendations largely related to a possible linkage which the committee believed would be a useful starting point for more productive planning and development assistance, and for the debate on the appropriate priorities in the direction of Australia aid. And I would urge all members, especially those who have an interest in the aid question, to read that report.

BREAK.PARA: Seminars such as this are important not only to highlight issues of aid but also to assist members of parliament to better understand the complexities of the aid issues. There is a responsibility for members of parliament to take a lead on this issue. That is why it is particularly disappointing to see the views of one member, the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), getting such coverage. In an interesting article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 12 October, Mike Seccombe posed a number of questions. I will just comment on two which are related to this report. What if the government followed the advice of the honourable member for Oxley and withdrew from the United Nations? In this article he said:
this would place Australia in the company of a handful of tiny and pariah states. International affairs experts say this would badly hurt trade, and probably lead to boycotts of Australia.
Then, of course, we come to the other call by the honourable member for Oxley to cut foreign aid. What if we cut foreign aid? Mike Seccombe continues:

this would also be likely to harm international relations, particularly in the region, but could also hurt the domestic economy. Increasingly, Australian aid is not sent as money, but in goods and services sourced from local companies. The theory is that aid often greases the wheels of trade, although this is difficult to quantify.

So, I must say that I do not share the views of the honourable member for Oxley. In fact, I have not found anyone in this place who actually does. It is a great pity that, on such a sensitive issue as aid, her views are getting such wide publicity. I think that they are sending the wrong image out to the Australian people and, indeed, to our neighbours that many members of this House share that view. I have spoken to many members of this House and I have not yet found one who shares the views of the honourable member for Oxley. It would have, perhaps, helped her education and understanding of some of the aid issues on which she is commenting, if she had attended this seminar or, indeed, had read this report.

That is the world we now see and I doubt if there is one person in this building who is satisfied with that picture. Each one of us would like to see a better world. We hope to see a world in which every person has secure access to enough cheap food and clean water to sustain a healthy and productive life, a world in which children are well fed, a world in which the food is provided in a sustainable manner and a world where agriculture does not destroy or diminish the environment in which we live.

Again, I would like to commend the committee, especially the Chair, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) because I know that it was very much at his instigation that this seminar was organised. It brought great credit to the committee and to this parliament. It is an initiative that I would like to see the joint standing committee—of which I am very pleased to be a member—continue to pursue. I would like to see all of us here in this parliament become better versed in this question of aid.

Aid is often a difficult question. When we are out talking to people who may be out of work or who have problems we always, as members of parliament, hear the question, `Why should we give foreign aid? Charity should begin at home'. There is a case that can be put for aid and, as members of parliament, we should be putting that case and urging the government to continue with the aid program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) for his remarks. Like him, I thought the seminar was well worth while. I think that it is important that we not only, in our committee processes in this place, engage in full inquiries but where possible and practical we should also engage in a dialogue which allows not only members of parliament but those who would normally make submissions to the full inquiry to engage in discussions on matters of importance. I felt that this one-day seminar on the Australian aid program, which followed on from one that was conducted last year on Africa, and in which the honourable member for Throsby was also involved, was well worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: I would particularly like to extend to Margaret Swieringa, the secretary of the subcommittee on foreign affairs, and to Joanne Towner, the secretary of the full committee, my thanks for their efforts and cooperation. There is no doubt that without their efforts the seminar would have been far more difficult to arrange. Of course, it was really through their efforts that this report has been produced in this form.

One of the advantages of having this sort of report is that it means that there is now a base reference for those who participated in the seminar and for all those who have a general interest in aid. I have already spoken to a number of participants who have said that they have found the report very valuable. It is a concept which we can take on from here and perhaps use, from time to time, in other ways, although without derogation to normal full inquiries. It is an area where we allow people to come here and present their points of view and it gives us an opportunity to have our views exposed to them. That, of course, was very much the benefit of the day.

The report came forward with a number of recommendations and I want to identify some of those. Although it has been tabled in the House and there has been some identification in the formal presentation of the report, I think that, inevitably, with the report now under way by Dr Paul Simons, some of these issues are matters which I hope will enable people in the community to look at Australian aid perhaps a little bit more analytically than they have in the past.

It is very easy, for example, to assess aid only in the term of quantum, of money available. On the other hand, there are those—and particularly when people are in distress with high unemployment and with economic adversity—who say, `Why are we giving overseas aid at all?' There is no doubt that both sides of the argument are very strongly held. They are valid points of view and yet, from Australia's national perspective, I do not think that there is any doubt that the question is not whether to maintain aid but the direction where our aid heads that we need to be concerned with.

I want to say a little bit about that. One can see in the report the extent to which humanitarian aid has increased over the last few years. It is quite remarkable the way in which development assistance programs have been and continue to be eroded. Page 13 of the report points out that at the beginning of the 1980s the donor community spent about $300 million a year on emergency aid. Ten years later it had become $3.2 billion. The difficulty with emergency aid is not that it can in any way be reduced but it is unfortunately then used to reduce the amount of development assistance aid provided. That means that in many instances communities are not able to advance themselves to the degree or the extent that they might otherwise have.

It is important that we register that, while we do give quite a bit of assistance to NGOs, they raise a lot of their resources privately. Thirty per cent of the aid budget was provided in 1996‐97 to multilateral humanitarian and emergency programs. You have to realise that in addition to the government sector provision of aid the NGO community provided something like 47 percent of its expenditure to food aid and emergency assistance. Not only is emergency aid being given directly by way of the government; a great deal is being done through the NGO community.

There is also a deal of aid through the defence cooperation program given by way of assistance particularly in the South Pacific. As many would know, every time there is a cyclone or a hurricane in the South Pacific, the resources of the Department of Defence are called on. Quite properly, they are used to provide sometimes temporary accommodation for people affected, sometimes transport and generally backup for the services that otherwise are absolutely destroyed or non-existent. It is very important that the long‐term advantage of aid is registered as doing not much more than just providing that very temporary assistance. It is a matter of great concern, particularly if one looks at the poverty debate which is a very important element in the whole concept of where our aid goes.

Another aspect of the seminar that I found particularly interesting was the argument that was very strongly presented—and it is a point of view that I have always held—that, if one can help raise the living standards of people in a recipient country, that certainly helps that country in more ways than just that aid. In other words, you have to try to assess the degrees of development assistance. You can help a country to help itself. Australia has a very proud record of helping people and training people in recipient countries to undertake projects of their own.

We have a record of helping people in developing the skills necessary to build water storage, to operate pumps, to build and maintain roads and maintain bridges. I think it is important that that emphasis be maintained. I am particularly concerned because of the direction in which some aid programs of other countries have gone. They provide help, but they use their own nationals to provide the aid. The outcome is nowhere near what it would be if you left behind the knowledge of how to acquire certain skills for particular projects so that people could help themselves in the future. That is a very important element of our development assistance program, and it is one that is particularly important as far as the future focus of the report is concerned and of the AusAid emphasis.

The third important area is the degree to which business can play a role and be of assistance in the aid program. It was quite remarkable that some of those present at the seminar had not realised that, if they spoke to a businessman working in the area, there were ways in which they could help each other. I hope the dialogue that occurred for the first time at the seminar can be used by the NGOs to enable them to better access people with knowledge of the area and also direct business people as to how they can contribute towards the betterment of the economy and the people in the country where they are doing business.

It was surprising that so many in business had not been aware of the relationship that is possible with NGOs. Equally, the NGOs which, quite properly, are concerned about raising funds and which were saying how poor business support was, did not realise that, by cooperating with businesses operating in a particular recipient country area, they could piggyback on business, use it to assist them, and that a mutual partnership opportunity existed, one which I trust will be furthered.

In the report, we refer to the possibility of partnerships between the private sector, government and NGOs. We commented that it was apparent from discussions that the sectors had not previously recognised the contribution that each could make to the other's field of endeavour. It is particularly important that that be picked up and pursued.

BREAK.PARA: I am glad that my colleague the former chair of the foreign affairs and defence committee, the member for Chifley (Mr Price), is now in the Main Committee. He made a very worthwhile intervention in the area of peacekeeping proposals. One of the important parts of Australia's operation in peacekeeping has been not the military activity so much as the civilian extension of the project. One of the interventions of the honourable member for Chifley at the one‐day seminar was to suggest that we look more closely at the way in which, once we have a large Australian commitment, we maximise the long‐term benefit of that commitment.

I have not been to Somalia, but I am told that even today the only effective law enforcement in that country is based on the contribution made by the Australian peacekeeping detachment. That is not because the Australians are there but because they have enabled the resumption of some form of normalcy in the processes of law, in the way in which law is administered. I understand that it is Italian law which dates back to a period when the Italians were a colonial power. However, the nature of the law does not matter, it is the fact that there is a rule of law that is important.

It is particularly important, therefore, that we look at ways in which both defence cooperation aid and peacekeeping forces can extend the aid opportunity so that there is a marriage of the Australian commitment to what can be done in the long term to help the people with what is being done by the Australian defence or civilian personnel who are serving there.

In that respect, I have long had the view that we really need to look at police rather than military forces. So often in peacekeeping there is a real advantage if you can encourage the civilian administration of law rather than having military personnel. Having said that, when you have police, as we have had in Cyprus for 30 years, it is a worry that we have not yet found a way of putting an end date on our commitments.

One of my real concerns is that in peacekeeping generally there has to be not just a commitment but also an understanding of the purpose of the commitment. There has to be an understanding of the period of the commitment. Objectives must be laid down. I hope I have picked up the idea of the honourable member for Chifley about the importance of what will be left after their withdrawal, because that is particularly important.

Part of the objective of the seminar was to expose the issues and to look at the degree to which the announcement by the government that the development import finance facility, or the DIFF scheme, would not be proceeded with was a problem. That has become a matter for further debate in the House since the delivery of the budget. As one who has seen a little of the application of the DIFF scheme, and who introduced the export manufacturing development grants scheme proposal long since, I think it is important that we look at how business can be involved in extending Australian influence—if I can call it that—in recipient countries.

The DIFF scheme has advantages because it gives us the opportunity to provide business involvement in projects that would otherwise not be built at the time and, indeed, if they are built and they are built with World Bank or Asian Development Bank or some other funding, are not likely to be built by Australian companies.

The DIFF scheme having gone, I hope that something of its character can be re‐established, because I think there is reason for us to look at those major infrastructure programs. Together with a number of my colleagues, I had a look at the bridge that has been built across the Mekong, and a couple of weeks ago I had discussions with regard to the second bridge which is going to be built across the Mekong. They are symbolic but they are also significant; they are going to be people movers. The chairman, Mr Hollis, was with me when we went across the bridge into Laos, and there is no doubt that that link between Thailand and Laos is a tremendously important symbolic physical link. And you are not likely to embark on that sort of a project unless you have some way by which you can help business into it.

So I think all those are issues which, together with the other recommendations of the report, I would commend to Dr Paul Simons. I think it is important that he does not look at the seminar as just another part of the general dialogue. I think there were recommendations in it. Certainly there are some fundamental issues, the relationship between economic growth and the alleviation of poverty being one where there was a very vigorous debate at the seminar and where I am sure no resolution was reached. But it is an issue which needs to be addressed because those sorts of issues are going to have a considerable advantage in identifying the ways by which Australian aid can best be provided. After all, what we all seek is to help the countries where we give the aid so that in the long term they can help themselves and in due course they too can make their contribution to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) for initiating and chairing the seminar on foreign aid. It was a very valuable initiative and I know it continues his long interest in this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a timely moment to be reviewing development assistance, for several reasons. First of all, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said in his speech, about a quarter of humankind, 1.3 billion people, live in absolute poverty. Around 800 million of them are chronically malnourished. Despite rapid development in a number of countries, the number of people living in absolute poverty is still growing, and external assistance is one effective means of addressing that massive need.

Secondly, the volume of aid is falling. The unweighted Development Assistance Committee average fell from 0.45 per cent of GNP in 1994 to 0.41 per cent in 1995. In 1985, the figure was 0.46 per cent. So the volume of aid actually held up for most of the last decade until last year. Australian aid has been reduced from a two‐decade peak of 0.50 per cent in 1983‐84 to 0.29 per cent this year. One of the most destructive decisions in the Howard government's first budget was to reduce aid this year compared with 1995‐96 by $155 million in real terms.

This is driven by the decision of government to reduce outlays rather than by aid fatigue amongst voters. It is a clear example of the dominance of narrow economic doctrine over proper political processes. It would be surprising if two decades of the propaganda of mean‐spirited economists in the public sector and a decade of greed in parts of the private sector had not eroded public generosity. Yet the evidence suggests that there is still a widespread general level of support for the aid program. That is particularly concentrated in disaster relief, but it is a general level of support for development cooperation.

This support is soft, however, because there is great ignorance about the aid program. There has been some growth of scepticism about the effectiveness of aid, including concern about the honesty with which aid funds are handled in some countries. There is also awareness of the contribution of aid to the success of countries in East Asia, and so questioning about the continued need for development assistance to those countries. So there is a combination of a degree of complacency and of some despair around.

The structure of the Australian aid program since the Jackson report a dozen years ago has changed to give a greater attention to countries in the Asia‐Pacific region and to social development. However, the proportion of funds being channelled through the multilateral agencies has also increased very substantially, and that has been questioned by some. A more positive development is that there has been an increase in the proportion being allocated through non‐government organisations. The rapid growth of private financial flows to emerging markets also raises the issue of whether aid is still required.

The seventh of the introductory points I want to make is that the rapid integration of the global economy is changing the context within which aid is given and received, and raises questions about the appropriateness of a voluntary system of development assistance when global interdependence is becoming so strong. For example, is it enough simply to offer assistance to countries with emerging capital markets for the management of their financial systems when disorder in one can rapidly cause disorder in many? With rapid growth in the volume of pension funds from advanced economies being invested in emerging markets, the case for external assistance to support effective, equitable, tension reducing economic and social development is strengthened.

I want to make a few comments on those introductory points. The rationale for development assistance remains very strong. First, it is clear that there is massive need—for food; for housing; for income earning opportunities; for work; for education; for health services; for infrastructure; for access to markets; for honest legal and financial systems; for information, not least about family planning techniques; for technology; for improved plant and animal varieties; for appropriate technologies; and for access to loanable funds for some people in most countries of the world, and for many in most.

External assistance is one effective means of supporting tackling each of those needs, provided it is given or lent in ways which have learnt from the vast and diverse experience of the last 50 years. Universal economic and social development is in the interest of all members of the global community, since economic development somewhere contributes to economic development everywhere and greater stability in one country contributes to increasing security in all the countries around us. The world has a shared interest in creating the conditions which facilitate economic security and social harmony everywhere.

During the first half of the 1990s, private financial flows have added substantially to the resources of some developing countries, but most of this private investment has been concentrated in fewer than a dozen countries. Further increases in private financial flows to emerging countries may well occur as confidence in their profitability and reliability improves, but this offers little potential benefit for most low income countries. Concessional assistance will have vital role in the foreseeable future. The question is how this can be generated in the current fiscal climate.

A major change in the aid paradigm would be valuable. The need to offset global market failure offers a way forward. During the last couple of decades there has been a striking increase in the extent of global integration. The explosive growth in the integration and size of global financial markets is a particularly clear example.

One effect of this growing interdependence is diminished national autonomy. There are two obvious responses. One is for governments, the private sector and civil society to seek to act as effectively as possible within the limits, aiming for the best available outcomes from national policies and action within the global constraints. The other is for countries to act together to achieve agreed goals. The role of the UN, the IMF and the World Bank is to facilitate such cooperation.

BREAK.PARA: A conceptual shift is required, a central aspect of which must be recognition of the pervasiveness of global market failure and of the incapacity of nations acting alone to cope, and of the necessity for cooperative international action to offset such failure. Just as national governments cope with market failure within their countries by organising the provision of public goods, so the international community is being compelled to respond to international market failure through expanding the provision of global public goods.

A particularly important aspect of market failure is the inability of the private sector to provide goods and services which automatically benefit everyone. This is the reason for such national public goods as the law and order system, roads, public health services and public education. It is also the principal rationale for such global public goods as the International Telecommunications Union and the services it provides, the International Civil Aviation Organisation and the World Meteorological Organisation. Their services are global public goods.

Unless every country is required to contribute to the cost of these services, the `free rider' problem arises. Allowing voluntary payment would be unfair because some countries would benefit without contributing to the cost of provision. The decline in development cooperation aid is partly due to the free rider problem. The motivation to provide aid is reduced when other countries offer little or are reducing their aid. The frequency of international aid comparisons are a clear example of this.

During the last decade, there have been some significant extensions of global public goods, such as the negotiation and implementation of the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, and the Framework Convention on Climate Change, as well as the establishment of the World Trade Organisation. However, a growing range of issues remain unaddressed or are given inadequate attention. Examples include provision of swift, adequate, emergency relief and support in response to natural disasters or to the consequences of civil war; international financial volatility; competition between countries over tax rates; economic coordination and stabilisation; drug trafficking; international migration; and protection of the global environment and management of the global commons—let alone the continuing issues of improving global economic performance by facilitating economic development in poorer countries and of improving security for all through peacekeeping and peacemaking.

Public support for expansion of the provision of global public goods will certainly increase as more governments become aware that this is the only way to equitably share the costs of effective provision—a calculation which should take only a few minutes once the issue is seriously addressed. This situation is called the `prisoner's dilemma' by economists because, unless all beneficiaries are compelled to contribute, the motivation for one or a few to provide the service voluntarily is severely undermined, since they know that non‐contributors will benefit.

A crucial question is how to pay for an expanded range of global public goods. Many proposals have been made, including borrowing, user‐pays fees, increased compulsory subscriptions and new taxes, such as on air travel, telecommunications, use of energy or the arms race. One possibility which deserves particular attention is a small levy on foreign exchange transactions—the Tobin tax. This would contribute to stabilising financial markets, as well as to raising revenue for governments and for international global public goods. The rationale for international revenue raising is now very strong. With growing globalisation, an increasing number of issues must be addressed, in part at least, on a global basis. Yet they remain inadequate, because of a combination of the free rider problem and the prisoner's dilemma.

If this new paradigm became more widely accepted, there would be a dramatic change in the framework for economic and social development assistance. The world would move out of the era of voluntary charity, which is essentially the nature of the current aid framework, into an era of effective universal global infrastructures. This is the transition which industrial countries began to make early in the 20th century. The logic of such an international extension is watertight. Political leadership will still be required to make the transition, but pressure of circumstances will force the process to some extent. The extension of global public goods is inevitable in an orderly world. The issue is the speed and effectiveness with which the evolution occurs. The sooner it happens, the more effectively underdevelopment and poverty will be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in my remarks on the report of the seminar held by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian aid program. At the outset I will put on the record that I did not have the opportunity to attend the seminar held in Canberra on 31 July because of parliamentary and electoral commitments in the Northern Territory. I would dearly like to have attended because of the close proximity of the Northern Territory, especially Darwin, to our Asian neighbours to the north.

SPEECH.PARA: The seminar was particularly timely as it coincided with the United Nations' International Year for the Eradication of Poverty. The conclusions of the seminar were that it was a very good starting point for future debate and that it was needed because it had been a number of years since the Jackson report which was a comprehensive study of overseas aid provided by Australia. I am aware that Paul Simons has been appointed by the government to undertake a review of Australia's aid program and that that will be a report that I am quite sure many of my colleagues will be waiting for.

The seminar was conducted prior to the coalition's budget. Reading the report, I think an underlying factor was what the aid program was going to receive in light of the government's facing very severe budget constraints. I believe people at the seminar were very mindful of what kind of aid might be provided in the coalition budget. For the record, I would like to quote from the section on the budget in the report. Section 2.6 says:

In the 1996 budget, aid received $1.45 billion, a cut of $114.4 million or 10 per cent from the previous year. The cut was made up of $93.4 million from the abolition of the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) Scheme and $64.9 million from country aid programs. Increases were made to compensate China, the Philippines and Indonesia for the abandonment of DIFF projects but they did not offset overall loses. Overall reductions to China will be $20 million, to Indonesia $21 million, to the Philippines $14 million, Thailand $11 million and Malaysia $14 million. Further savings are to be made from the administrative costs in AusAID. At the same time there is a small increase of some $16.9 million in the contributions to multilateral organisations such as the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the International Fund for Agricultural Development.
I think it is important to have that in this report because, at the time, there were rumours around saying that aid programs were going to be very seriously curtailed.

Australia over the last few years has been leading the way in providing resources to those countries in need. But, in view of the economic climate, while the 10 per cent cut may seem extravagant to some people I believe it was in accordance with government policy. The important thing in terms of the region is that it is good to see that business leaders attended the seminar and that their interest in developing our region was quite prominent in the contributions they made.

There are couple of points I would like to talk about in relation to the aid program and its effect in some small instances on the Northern Territory. AusAid was able to provide financial assistance to some 18 midwives who came to Darwin in April this year to train. The scheme was funded by AusAid and the midwives came from most of the rural areas of Indonesia. They came for training in Darwin to improve their education and skills, so that when they went back to Indonesia they would be able to pass on that information and assist in the education and training of others in that field.

That training is very important—it is vital—because the infant mortality in rural Indonesia runs to about four out of 100, that is, four per cent. It is very high, when one considers that there are something like 65,000 villages and roughly 40,000 midwives in Indonesia, many of whom lack experience and some of whom are quite young.

This program was undertaken by the Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry in the Northern Territory, through its international project management unit in conjunction with the Northern Territory University. The university made a bid for the Australian component for this master midwifery train the trainer program. It is part of the Indonesian government's long‐term strategy to improve the health and welfare of mothers and babies, especially in rural areas. I understand that the participants worked very hard. It took them three months to do the course in Darwin, but before they came to Darwin they had to undertake a rapid course to learn to speak English. I understand that they acquitted themselves quite well.

Somewhere along the line, the results of this type of aid, especially coming out of the regional areas where you have another Australian government involved with the federal government and with a foreign government, have to be successful because of the commitment of the three organisations, all being government organisations.

The other particular section related to the Northern Territory and the impact of the DIFF program, which has been abolished by the coalition government because of the problems with getting the required outcomes from the program. There was another organisation in the Northern Territory called Integrated Technical Services, with another company called Solarex. They had to put in a bid to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for aid funding to provide solar energy in the rural parts of Indonesia. That program, as we have since heard, was supported by the Indonesian government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs has now seen his way clear to make some provision to allow that particular part of the DIFF program to proceed in terms of providing solar energy in the various parts of Indonesia, especially the remote parts, through a territory company.

There are other instances where good use of aid to Indonesia can come out of the Australian scene. Another territory company at the moment is specialising in providing remote area services for drainage and sewerage. A lot of honourable members would be aware that providing infrastructure for sewerage for the communities can be a very costly exercise. I think that is where it starts: if some of the communities have good health, are clean and have no problems of disease because of overflowing sewage, then obviously anything that could be done or put in place to alleviate such dangers to other communities would be very important.

I believe that there is a territory company that now has the capacity to provide septic sewerage for remote areas. In fact, it has been trialling it quite well in the Northern Territory, in some of our Aboriginal communities. Hopefully, the benefit from the trial periods in the Northern Territory will have some impact in terms of what can be done in the overseas region, where you have large populations in remote areas spread out throughout their country.
The other particular area that I want to speak about related section 3.17, at page 15 of the report. It stated:
In respect of the educational programs within the Australian aid program, Ms Wynne—
who was from World Vision—

was critical of the present program for what she saw as too great an emphasis on the tertiary sector, particularly what she saw as the expensive process of bringing students to Australia to study. Mr Kanaley—
who was the director of AusAid—

disagreed with this interpretation of the educational sector of the aid program but also defended the tertiary program in terms of comparative advantage—Australia being better at tertiary education from which we derived influence on the educated elites of neighbouring countries and recipient countries being better at primary education and basic literacy in their own languages.

There you have two people making statements at the seminar who had some slight conflict. But the reason I brought it up is that, in terms of education in remote areas, I am aware that there is an Australian company which has support from the Indonesian Directorate of Remote Teaching Services to provide technology in remote areas in Indonesia whereby it is all done by satellite communication. We are talking about remote areas, but they do have television in remote areas, they do have some power, and those areas that have the capacity to accept a signal should be considered. There are something like 85,000 primary school teachers in Indonesia and its population in remote areas is in excess of 100 million, and it could be, I believe, a good teaching aid.

The government could investigate this application by an Australian company in terms of the provision of service. The company wants to have a core unit of teachers broadcasting to the remote areas. In other words, you would have a primary school teacher talking by satellite to other primary school teachers in remote areas, who would then go and use that experience in teaching the children in their classroom. Moving around the Indonesian archipelago and all the islands is very difficult and very expensive and, in some cases, I believe, does not get the full support of the Indonesian government. But remote teaching by satellite certainly could be part of the aid program that we provide.

I know that the Indonesians, in terms of their own aid programs that they request from the World Bank and from other countries, do have a priority book. It was already known to me a couple of years ago that the Indonesian Ministry of Education did accord a high priority to the application that the company was making in terms of getting some aid funding for it to proceed.

So there are a lot of things that can be done that would help people, and obviously that is the whole aim of providing aid, to provide the necessary equipment, the necessary skills or the necessary training to help our northern neighbours make improvements in health, education and social welfare. One of the most important things in many of the remote areas of Indonesia is that they do lack proper training and proper facilities, and that can only come through education. I believe that the aid program that has been earmarked for the Indonesian region has some benefit to them and I believe it will have a long‐term benefit for the Australian community.

BREAK.PARA: As I said earlier, I believe that we have made an important contribution to the region to our immediate north. Other members of the committee, who have been involved with the committee a lot longer than I, have seen the benefits of aid programs that have been provided to many other countries around the world.

The seminar was very well attended, and I would like to congratulate the secretary of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Ms Towner, for putting such a wonderful effort into making sure that the seminar was a success for all those who participated. I would also like congratulate the chairman of the committee, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), for the part that he played in making sure the seminar was conducted in a satisfactory manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start where the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) finished and congratulate the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, for the initiative of holding the seminar in conjunction with Community Aid Abroad, World Vision and the Australian Council for Overseas Aid.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that committees of the parliament are relevant to the Australian people. We have sometimes fallen into the trap of seeing the benefits of committees merely in terms of the number of magnum opus reports that they deliver. I am not saying that there is not a role for that, but the seminar initiative taken by the committee and the chairman was a very good one. It was certainly topical in view of the controversy surrounding the cutting of DIFF funding and the announcement of a review of aid. I hope we will see more such seminars. I would also like to congratulate Margaret Swieringa for her continuing good work for the committee, and the secretary of the committee, Joanne Towner.

Things have changed a little since that seminar. A notable first speech has been made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) that has set a few hares running in this country—rather regrettable hares, I must say. In my area I used to be questioned quite frequently by members of the public and my branch members about why Australia gave overseas aid. I would always do my best to answer those questions, but I was not able to convince people until I described some of the very worthwhile Australian aid projects and the impact they had on individual countries. I have not been quizzed on aid for some time.

In relation to the statement by the member for Oxley, this is the first opportunity I have had to say that one of my local newspapers ran an article asking how many people supported the member for Oxley and how many of my constituents were opposed to what she said. The overwhelming majority were in favour of her views. Let me restate, though, that I still think Australia is a marvellous country; a nation with many different cultures.

I have some comments to make about the member's remarks about Asians. The fastest growing segment of Blacktown is the Filipino community. They make a wonderful contribution. They have the advantage that they speak English, which I think makes their introduction to this country a lot easier. They are absolutely fixated on family life and owning a home. I have often said to them that one of their big problems is that they all too quickly forget the culture they have brought to this country. That is indicative of the way they rapidly integrate into our community.

To return to the main points of the committee's report, The Australian aid program, I have often said in this place and in my electorate that if I had one wish it would be that all my constituents could travel overseas and see what goes on in other countries. I always return to Australia feeling very privileged to have visited other countries, but I am also delighted to be back in Australia because it is a wonderful place.

Other speakers have pointed out that approximately 800 million to 1.3 billion people live in absolute poverty in the world today. About one billion people do not have access to basic health services; 1.3 billion do not have access to safe water; two billion do not have access to sanitation services, and approximately 30 per cent of the land in Africa is affected by significant degradation, as is about 20 per cent of the land in Asia. There are about 54 million refugees and displaced persons in the world today. To add to that list of need, the unmet infrastructure needs in East Asia alone require some $1.9 trillion in investment over the next decade.

There can be people in our country who advocate a larger defence vote, that we should be able to better protect ourselves. In fact, I wish that were possible, but it is not. The point that I want to make is that we are not going to be able to put barbed wire around Australia. It is in our security interests to alleviate poverty wherever it is because that poverty is going to be the single source of unrest and disquiet.

In the recommendations of the report is another theme. Just allowing people to be out of poverty but not enjoy other benefits of a democracy—that is, the rule of law, title to land, the ability to vote in and out representatives, all these things go to build a safer and more stable world—is not enough. As much as we might like to become super‐isolationists in Australia, that is not going to be a viable policy, or a good long‐term policy. Our best long‐term policy, I believe, is being good, world corporate citizens. In a country blessed with the riches that we do have, that really means that we have an obligation to assist others. That ought to be a feeling shared not just by the righteous in the community, but by every level in community. On straight cost benefit and hard analysis alone, we have a big stake. We have a lot to benefit from having a robust aid program.

Probably, the former government has been more responsible than others in suggesting that we need to focus on Asia. I certainly believe that. I think that that is a good thing. But all too often it has been interpreted somehow as though we do not have obligations to other parts of the world. When we become members of things like the United Nations and other world bodies, we sign up as world citizens—not half citizens, not quarter citizens, but full world citizens. Let me say this: if we do not see the African continent as part of our high priority area, then as we go into the next millennium, unless we can see the condition of the African people improve economically as well as in human rights terms, it is going to be a continual source of problems for us and the rest of the world. We have a great interest in trying to build on the foundations that have come with the ending of apartheid in South Africa, and in ensuring that other southern African countries enjoy democracy, economic progress and the fruits of the rule of law. Regrettably, at the moment, as much as some of us are African optimists, really, the prospects are not that good. I want to just make that point.

The right honourable member for New England mentioned peacekeeping. I believe that we certainly need to better plan at the United Nation level for peacekeeping operations. To believe that you can send troops in, then pull them out and withdraw and everything is going to be fixed, is really Alice in Wonderland. We really do need to have an active program of rehabilitation and reconstruction for the country so that the peace is lasting.

I will finish on this point. One of the real gaps that came out of the seminar was the lack of understanding between companies who were participating and NGOs. If the seminar did anything it brought about a commencement of a dialogue and, in terms of the recommendations, we are seeking to have that dialogue increase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speakers, I welcome the opportunity to speak briefly on the motion to take note of the report of the seminar on the Australian foreign aid program by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. As a long term supporter and campaigner for several organisations heavily involved in Australia's overseas aid program, it has been very interesting for me to read this report and to note the recommendations contained therein. Like other speakers, I would also like to congratulate the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) for his foresight in having his committee convene the seminar to discuss in general terms the Australian aid program .

SPEECH.PARA: As previous speakers have also noted, since the March 1996 election certain members of this House have really challenged us to think long and hard on the issues of Australia's involvement in the area of foreign aid. Those who have known me have often heard me say that if you have nothing nice to say about someone, keep your mouth shut. With that in mind, I would like to counteract in a positive way what I see as some rather intolerant remarks both by some members of this House and by some of the media commentators who are peddling populist views which seem to be gaining favour with the various media outlets and driving commentary in this country.

The doers in this society are appalled at this new wave of populism which sees overseas aid and development as something that is irrelevant and unnecessary. We hear the catchcry, `Let's fix our own backyard first. Why should we care about these people?' In the few moments I have allocated to me I would like to put on record examples of two movements that I have been long aware of, but that some people might not be.

I recently attended a Results International conference in Washington DC where I met one of the people who are having a profound influence on the world. This lady is Dr Vicky Guzman. She is the founder and director of an organisation called ASAPROSAR in El Salvador. She completed her medical training in 1972 and then decided to work in the mountainous areas of western El Salvador, treating people and training health workers in each of the villages. Poverty, illiteracy and disease were rampant and many children died of diarrhoea, malnutrition and parasites.

Through her good work she managed to convince, through the civil war period, the Campesino leaders from the rural mountain areas whom she managed to train as health promoters in their various villages. Despite the civil war, after 10 years of operation ASAPROSAR has achieved what I guess you could call monumental monuments to their success. In 10 years it has increased its service to approximately 80,000 people in the rural mountain districts of western El Salvador. It has grown from a staff of one physician—Dr Guzman—and three social workers to a staff of over 50 people. They have established three rural clinics and eight maternal child health centres. More remarkably, they have trained 800 volunteer promoters in health, midwifery, child development and early intervention programs, and have hugely decreased the morbidity and mortality rates of children in that part of El Salvador.

The other spectacular organisation is the Grameen Bank, which many members might not be aware of. Twenty‐two years ago in a village in Bangladesh, Dr Yunus, a professor of economics at the nearby university, happened to come across a young villager who was desperately trying to alleviate the poverty in her village. She used to weave bamboo furniture and was desperately in need of some capital. The going rate at the time was 300 per cent interest a year. Most of the world's poor are caught in this trap—they are thoroughly exploited either by their employer or the money‐lending elite. They cannot borrow from banks because they cannot provide any collateral.

With a few dollars loan from the professor, it took this young villager only a few months to establish her own self‐employment. She increased her income sevenfold and repaid the loan. From this modest beginning grew a bank which today employs 12,000 staff—unlike some of the banks in this country—works in 35,000 villages of Bangladesh and extends four million loans a year. In just the past two years it has extended half of the money which it has lent over the past two decades. Each month it extends new loans totalling between $US30 million and $US40 million and its loan repayments exceed 99.5 per cent, which means it outperforms all other banks in Bangladesh and most banks around the world.

It is interesting that this debate is being held today, the day before the one set aside—probably most people do not know—as the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty. This is the International Year for the Eradication of Poverty. The United Nations has dedicated this year as the beginning of the decade to end poverty. There are more than sufficient resources in the world; what is required is the will to achieve it. There is an emerging groundswell of opinion in the community towards ridding the world of the evils of hunger and poverty.

Six years ago in September, 140 countries were represented at the World Summit for Children. Australia was included at that gathering. Six years ago, governments throughout the world committed themselves to achieving a set of goals by the year 2000. These included reduction of child mortality by one third; reduction in child malnutrition by half; cutting of infant mortality by half; access to primary education, with completion by 80 per cent; and universal access to safe drinking water and sanitation. In the last few years there have been some notable achievements directed at achieving these goals. For example, 108 countries have achieved the 1995 interim target of 80 per cent immunisation—probably a figure in excess of what is achievable here in Australia—and 45 have achieved the year 2000 target of 90 per cent.

It is interesting to note the mention by the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) of the fact that 358 billionaires in this world have more income than 45 per cent of the world's population. Put that alongside the fact that between 35,000 and 40,000 children are dying daily from preventable diseases like measles, diarrhoea and whooping cough. We have one billion people living in absolute poverty and the gap between the rich and poor continues to widen.

As I said, there is a desire and a will. It is incumbent upon us as federal politicians to set ourselves a goal of having the political will to try to resolve some of these seemingly insurmountable problems. Tomorrow a multi‐partisan parliamentary group is going to be formed to provide an avenue for ongoing lobbying on the issue of Australia's commitment on international aid. Hopefully, this group will agree as one of its aims to set itself up as a council of parliamentarians. We have done this because in February next year a micro‐credit summit in Washington DC will attract close to 4,000 participants from around the world. Their goal is to promote and set about achieving some of the goals that this international decade for the eradication of poverty has as its main aims.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

(3) What role has SkillShare played with respect to labour market programs.
